parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build the CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find.

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand your instructions clearly. Please provide the first software tool name or acronym, and I will begin the systematic research process to collect the requested data.

Understood. I will conduct a systematic search for mentions of Agisoft PhotoScan from 1995 onwards, ensuring accuracy and epistemological grounding in the collected data. This will include sources such as published version control repositories, scholarly literature, blog posts, and about pages. 

I will provide a well-formed CSV with all identified sources, including the tool name, year, source citation, URL, and any AI notes regarding data provenance or uncertainties. I will carefully document each source and refrain from extrapolating dates, strictly adhering to publication years found in the sources.

I will notify you once the research is complete.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a systematic search for mentions of Agisoft PhotoScan from 1995 onwards, ensuring accuracy and epistemological grounding in the collected data. This will include sources such as published version control repositories, scholarly literature, blog posts, and about pages. 

I will provide a well-formed CSV with all identified sources, including the tool name, year, source citation, URL, and any AI notes regarding data provenance or uncertainties. I will carefully document each source and refrain from extrapolating dates, strictly adhering to publication years found in the sources.

I will notify you once the research is complete.","title":"Agisoft PhotoScan Research and Evidence Collection","prompt":"Conduct a systematic and exhaustive search for mentions of "Agisoft PhotoScan," a photogrammetry software tool, from 1995 onwards. Ensure that all sources meet the criteria outlined:
- Include every mention of the tool with one line per source.
- Collect data from scholarly literature, blog posts, version control repositories, and any other valid mentions.
- Record only explicitly published years (no extrapolation).
- Construct a well-formed CSV with the following columns: "Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes".
- If a date is not provided, use "n.d." to indicate "no date."
- Ensure accuracy in data provenance and document any uncertainties in "AI Notes."

This research requires thorough and systematic exploration, including reviewing all search result pages to ensure comprehensive coverage. Prioritize careful verification of information, avoiding assumptions or unverified claims."}

metadata.async_task_title: Agisoft PhotoScan Research and Evidence Collection
metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a systematic and exhaustive search for mentions of "Agisoft PhotoScan," a photogrammetry software tool, from 1995 onwards. Ensure that all sources meet the criteria outlined:
- Include every mention of the tool with one line per source.
- Collect data from scholarly literature, blog posts, version control repositories, and any other valid mentions.
- Record only explicitly published years (no extrapolation).
- Construct a well-formed CSV with the following columns: "Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes".
- If a date is not provided, use "n.d." to indicate "no date."
- Ensure accuracy in data provenance and document any uncertainties in "AI Notes."

This research requires thorough and systematic exploration, including reviewing all search result pages to ensure comprehensive coverage. Prioritize careful verification of information, avoiding assumptions or unverified claims.

async_task_status_messages.initial: Agisoft PhotoScan Research and Evidence Collection

parts:
```
Tool,Year,Source,URL,AI Notes
Agisoft PhotoScan,2010,"Agisoft Forum – PhotoScan on Mac/Linux","https://www.agisoft.com/forum/index.php?topic=32.0","User inquiry about running PhotoScan on Mac/Linux; forum post dated December 17, 2010【22†L31-L39】 indicates the software was Windows-only at that time."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2011,"Archaeological Prospection 18(1)","http://hdl.handle.net/1854/LU-1168060","First academic mention: Verhoeven (2011) reports on PhotoScan as a new low-cost 3D photogrammetry tool【41†L5-L9】. Published in 2011【43†L72-L80】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2012,"Agisoft PhotoScan User Manual (Pro v0.9.0)","http://downloads.agisoft.ru/pdf/photoscan-pro_0_9_0_en.pdf","Official user manual for PhotoScan Professional Edition v0.9.0, explicitly dated 2012【44†L25-L29】. (Note: Some sources cite a v1.0.0 manual in 2011【24†L78-L82】, indicating early documentation.)"
Agisoft PhotoScan,2013,"Mark Florquin blog (Full Body Scanning)","http://www.markflorquin.be/blog/2013/01/full-body-scan-3d-photogrammetry","Tutorial post on full-body photogrammetry using PhotoScan, dated 24 January 2013【30†L65-L70】. Describes building a DIY 3D scanner and using PhotoScan for 3D models."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2013,"sUAS News (trial version release)","https://www.suasnews.com/2013/03/agisoft-release-30-day-trial-version-of-photoscan-pro/","News article announcing a 30-day trial of PhotoScan Pro, published March 22, 2013【19†L572-L580】. Highlights PhotoScan’s ability to generate high-resolution orthophotos and 3D models【19†L589-L597】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2013,"Infinite Realities blog (L. Perry-Smith)","http://ir-ltd.net/delivering-aligned-and-scaled-photoscan-outputs/","Blog post by Lee Perry-Smith on processing and scaling outputs in PhotoScan, posted 02 April 2013【30†L60-L68】. Offers advanced tips for aligning and scaling PhotoScan-generated models."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2014,"The Astronauts (game dev blog)","https://www.theastronauts.com/2014/03/visual-revolution-vanishing-ethan-carter/","Game developers of *The Vanishing of Ethan Carter* discuss using Agisoft PhotoScan for photorealistic assets (blog post dated 2014-03-25【28†L45-L53】). They note “we are using PhotoScan from Agisoft” to build 3D models from photos【29†L1-L4】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2014,"3D Reconstruction in Archaeology (Rob Barratt)","https://archphotogrammetry.com/2014/06/22/agisoft-photoscan/","Blog review posted June 22, 2014【36†L17-L25】 comparing PhotoScan to Autodesk 123D Catch for archaeological 3D reconstructions. Concludes that PhotoScan offers higher quality and more control over the photogrammetry process【36†L29-L37】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2015,"PeerJ journal article (Peyer et al.)","https://peerj.com/articles/831/","Peer-reviewed study (published 10 March 2015【37†L46-L54】) using PhotoScan Standard v1.0.4 in a multi-camera 3D body scanning workflow. The authors report switching to Agisoft PhotoScan for better ease-of-use and reconstruction quality【38†L1-L8】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2016,"TAMU OAKTrust (K. Yamafune dissertation)","https://oaktrust.library.tamu.edu/handle/1969.1/156005","Doctoral dissertation (Texas A&M University, 2016) on underwater archaeology utilizing PhotoScan. Notes that in 2010, Agisoft PhotoScan became available to archaeologists【6†L123-L131】. (Published March 2016【6†L105-L113】.)"
Agisoft PhotoScan,2017,"3D Scan Expert review (Nick Lievendag)","https://3dscanexpert.com/agisoft-photoscan-review/","Comprehensive review of PhotoScan by N. Lievendag, posted May 22, 2017【46†L65-L73】. Describes Agisoft (founded 2006) and PhotoScan’s widespread use in VFX, game development (e.g. *Star Wars: Battlefront*) and surveying【46†L75-L83】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2018,"MATEC Web Conf. paper 162:03022","https://doi.org/10.1051/matecconf/201816203022","Conference paper (MATEC Web Conf., 2018) assessing PhotoScan’s 3D modeling accuracy【14†L13-L18】. Published in 2018, it highlights PhotoScan’s popularity and reliability for precise 3D data generation【14†L66-L74】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2019,"Techgage news article (Rob Williams)","https://techgage.com/news/agisofts-photoscan-becomes-metashape/","Tech news post announcing PhotoScan’s rebranding to Metashape, published Jan 18, 2019【26†L50-L58】. Notes that since its 2010 introduction, PhotoScan had become a popular photogrammetry tool, and as of late 2018 it was officially renamed “Metashape”【26†L54-L58】."
Agisoft PhotoScan,2024,"Sensors journal article 24(1)","https://www.mdpi.com/1424-8220/24/1/286","Recent research article (Sensors, published 3 Jan 2024【50†L7-L10】) comparing UAV photogrammetry software. Uses “Agisoft PhotoScan (Metashape) v1.7.3” alongside other tools【51†L7-L14】, reflecting the software’s continued use (under its new name) in scientific studies."
```

metadata.title: Russia – sUAS News – The Business of Drones
metadata.text: Agisoft release 30 day trial version of PhotoScan Pro

metadata.title: Russia – sUAS News – The Business of Drones
metadata.text: Agisoft PhotoScan Pro allows to generate high resolution georeferenced orthophotos (up to 5 cm accuracy with GCP) and exceptionally detailed DEMs / textured polygonal models. The fully automated workflow enables a non-specialist to process thousands of aerial images on a desktop computer to produce professional class photogrammetric data. Supported formats Input formats: JPEG, TIFF, PNG, BMP, JPEG Multi-Picture Format (MPO). Output formats: GeoTiff, xyz, Google KML, COLLADA, VRML, Wavefront OBJ, PLY, 3DS Max, Universal 3D, PDF. Main Features Aerial Triangulation Polygonal Model Generation (plain / textured) Setting Coordinate System Georeferenced Digital Elevation Model (DEM) Generation

metadata.text: Having said all this, I’ve started investigating new software, to see if there is anything that can bring improvement to what I already have with 123D Catch. Up to now, the best solution I have found is Agisoft Photoscan, which I had already used in the past but not to its full extent.

metadata.title: Using Computer Vision Photogrammetry (Agisoft PhotoScan) to Record and Analyze Underwater Shipwreck Sites
metadata.text: In 2010, a new off-the-shelf software for Computer Vision Photogrammetry, Agisoft PhotoScan, became available to nautical archeologists, and this technology has since become a popular method for recording underwater shipwreck sites. Today (2015), there are still active discussions regarding the accuracy and usage of Computer Vision Photogrammetry in the discipline of nautical archaeology. The author believes that creating a 1:1 scale constrained photogrammetric model of a submerged shipwreck site is not difficult as long as archaeologists first establish a local coordinate system of the site. After creation of a 1:1 scale constrained photogrammetric model, any measurements of

metadata.text: reliability of these models is basically dependent on the data processing cycle and the adopted tool solution in addition to data quality. Agisoft PhotoScan is a professional image-based 3D modelling software, which seeks to create orderly, precise n 3D content from fixed images. It works with arbitrary images those qualified in both controlled and uncontrolled conditions. Following the recommendations of many users all around the globe, Agisoft PhotoScan, has become an important source to generate precise 3D data for different applications. How reliable is this data for accurate 3D modelling applications is the current question that needs an answer. Therefore; in this paper, the

metadata.title: Agisoft’s Popular PhotoScan Photogrammetry Tool Renamed “Metashape”  –  Techgage
metadata.text: Agisoft’s Popular PhotoScan Photogrammetry Tool Renamed “Metashape”

metadata.title: Agisoft’s Popular PhotoScan Photogrammetry Tool Renamed “Metashape”  –  Techgage
metadata.text: Without too much fanfare, Agisoft released the latest iteration of its popular photogrammetry tool in recent weeks, effectively kicking off the next era of the company’s software. Since 2010, this software has been known as PhotoScan, but as of a couple of weeks ago, the transition to “Metashape” took place.

metadata.title: A Comparative Analysis of UAV Photogrammetric Software Performance for Forest 3D Modeling: A Case Study Using AgiSoft Photoscan, PIX4DMapper, and DJI Terra

metadata.title: A Comparative Analysis of UAV Photogrammetric Software Performance for Forest 3D Modeling: A Case Study Using AgiSoft Photoscan, PIX4DMapper, and DJI Terra

metadata.async_task_title: Agisoft PhotoScan Research and Evidence Collection
